body:
For the directory module, if the path does not exist, we should continue to display it with an indicator that the path is no longer valid, e.g.

`/tmp/dummy_dir (deleted)`

For modules that rely on scanning `pwd`, it's not so clear how to redirect them in a way that doesn't crash. Perhaps the simplest option would be to make the working directory an `Option`, then follow the compiler errors to refactor other modules.

If the user has disabled all modules that scan `pwd`, including disabling the "truncate to repo" `directory` option, will the `directory` module still open the PWD? Because I don't think there's any need to open it just to do truncation behavior when "truncate to repo" is off.

Given that, the proposed ` (deleted)` bit should be disableable with a config flag, so users who disable everything else that scans pwd can disable that too and avoid having anything open PWD at all.

> Perhaps the simplest option would be to make the working directory an `Option`, then follow the compiler errors to refactor other modules.

I haven't looked at how the code is structured, but if "working directory" is a path rather than some sort of structure containing directory metadata, it shouldn't be optional. Just because the path doesn't exist on disk doesn't mean we don't have a path.

Modules in general should be resilient against filesystem errors. For example, what if PWD exists, but querying `$PWD/.git` gives me a permissions error?

issue.title: Starship breaks if you find yourself in a directory that doesn't exist

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
## Bug Report

If your PWD is a directory that no longer exists, you get a rust panic instead of a prompt.

#### Current Behavior
```
> mkdir /tmp/blah
> cd /tmp/blah
> rmdir /tmp/blah
thread 'main' panicked at 'Unable to identify current directory.: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }', src/libcore/result.rs:999:5
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace.
```
#### Expected Behavior
I would expect starship to present a prompt, possibly with some sort of warning or symbol to convey that you are in a directory that no longer exists.

#### Additional context/Screenshots

This happened to me when I did a `git checkout` of a branch that didn't contain the directory I was currently in, but can also be replicated by `cd`ing into a directory and then `rmdir`ing it.

#### Environment
- Starship version: 0.17.0
- Shell type: fish
- Shell version: 3.0.2
- Shell plugin manager: N/A
- Terminal emulator: iTerm2, 3.3.4
- Operating system: macOS 10.14.6

#### Relevant Shell Configuration

```fish
status --is-interactive; and source (rbenv init -|psub)
status --is-interactive; and source (nodenv init -|psub)
set -gx fish_user_paths ~/bin /usr/local/opt/coreutils/libexec/gnubin/ ~/go/bin /usr/local/Caskroom/google-cloud-sdk/latest/google-cloud-sdk/bin /opt/local/bin $fish_user_paths
set -gx FZF_DEFAULT_COMMAND 'fd --type f'
set -gx FZF_CTRL_T_COMMAND $FZF_DEFAULT_COMMAND
eval (starship init fish)
```

#### Starship Configuration
```toml
[git_status]
added = "‚ûï"
deleted = "üóë"

[character]
use_symbol_for_status = true

[directory]
fish_style_pwd_dir_length=22
```

issue.title: feat: add support for logical paths in directory

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->
<!--- To help with semantic versioning the PR title should start with one of the conventional commit types. -->
<!--- The conventional commit types for Semantic PR are: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, perf, test, build, ci, chore, revert -->

Adds support for displaying logical (as opposed to physical) paths on in the directory module.

This is a duplicate of #352, which was repeatedly failing due to (what seems like) a bug in GH Actions on clone. Hoping that a new PR works better.
#### Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->

Adds the ability for starship to display the logical path instead of the physical path. 

#### Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->

Physical paths are useful because there is usually only one canonical physical path. However, this physical path is sometimes not intuitive for users (e.g. `/storage/volumes/group/200/user/15ae2` as opposed to `~/storage`). The logical path is easier for the user to understand.

This PR adds an option to directory, `use_logical_path`. When it is set to `true` (which is its default value), the directory module attempts to use the `PWD` environment variable as the path instead of the path within context. If any of its lookups fail (e.g. because PWD is not valid unicode) it will fall back to using the physical path.

`PWD` appears to be a widely-accepted standard. For example, GNU Coreutils `pwd` uses this when running under `pwd -L` to try to get the logical path. Nonetheless, this may fail on systems like MacOS, BSD, Termux, and Windows.

Closes #270 

#### Types of changes
<!--- What types of changes does your code introduce? Put an `x` in all the boxes that apply: -->
- [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [x] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)

Breaking new feature?

If anyone is trying to parse the output of starship for some reason, this may break their setup because the current setting is to try to do logical paths by default. However, I don't anticipate any breakage in general.

#### Screenshots (if appropriate):

#### How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, tests ran to see how -->
<!--- your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
- [ ] I have tested using **MacOS**
- [x] I have tested using **Linux**
- [ ] I have tested using **Windows**

#### Checklist:
<!--- Go over all the following points, and put an `x` in all the boxes that apply. -->
<!--- If you're unsure about any of these, don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help! -->
- [x] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [x] I have updated the tests accordingly. (but they're failing)

issue.title: Starship panics if pwd does not have read permission

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
## Bug Report

#### Current Behavior

If pwd has permission `--x` (no read but allow navigation), starship panics with "Unable to read current directory". cd into these dirs works, though ls also fails with `
ls: cannot open directory '.': Permission denied`

#### Expected Behavior

No error.

#### Additional context/Screenshots

```
‚ùØ cd /var/lib/docker
thread 'main' panicked at 'Unable to read current directory: /var/lib/docker', src/context.rs:57:17                          
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace.
ls -alh
ls: cannot open directory '.': Permission denied
thread 'main' panicked at 'Unable to read current directory: /var/lib/docker', src/context.rs:57:17                          
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace.
cd ..

/var/lib 
‚ùØ ls -alh
drwx--x--x 1 root         root          188 Jun 30 15:51 docker
```

#### Environment
- Starship version: starship 0.17.0
- Shell type: zsh
- Shell version: zsh 5.7.1 (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu)
- Shell plugin manager: oh-my-zsh
- Terminal emulator: kitty
- Operating system: Arch

issue.title: Runtime Panic

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
## Bug Report

#### Current Behavior
Was doing `git pull --rebase`
thread 'main' panicked at 'Unable to identify current directory.: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }', src/libcore/result.rs:1084:5
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace.

#### Environment
- Starship version: starship 0.23.0
- Shell type: zsh
- Shell version: zsh 5.7.1 (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu)
- Shell plugin manager: oh-my-zsh
- Terminal emulator: kitty
- Operating system: Arch

#### Starship Configuration

```bash
# Don't print a new line at the start of the prompt
add_newline = false

# Replace the "‚ùØ" symbol in the prompt with "‚ûú"
[character]      # The name of the module we are confguring is "character"
symbol = "‚ûú"     # The "symbol" segment is being set to "‚ûú"

# Disable the package module, hiding it from the prompt completely
# [package]
# disabled = true

[git_branch]

truncation_length = "4"

[battery]

charging_symbol = "‚ö°Ô∏è"
discharging_symbol = "üíÄ"

[git_state]

modified = "Ôë¥ "
staged = "Ôòë "
ahead = "ÔßÑ"

[rust]
symbol = "Óû® "

[kubernetes]
symbol = "‚õµ "
style = "dim green"
disabled = false

```

body:
Please reopen, this just happened today in version 0.51.0:

```bash
thread 'main' panicked at 'Unable to identify current directory: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }', src/context.rs:69:51
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace
```

> Please reopen, this just happened today in version 0.51.0:
> 
> ```shell
> thread 'main' panicked at 'Unable to identify current directory: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }', src/context.rs:69:51
> note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace
> ```

I seem to be unable to reproduce this by deleting the directory starship is in.
Could you please create a new issue with steps to reproduce it, if possible? This seems to be a similar but separate issue.
This happens to me every time Starship is upgraded by `homebrew` - I have to close all my local terminals and reopen.

> I seem to be unable to reproduce this by deleting the directory starship is in.
> Could you please create a new issue with steps to reproduce it, if possible? This seems to be a similar but separate issue.

In terminal A:
```
$ mkdir aaa
$ cd aaa
```

Then terminal B:
```
$ rmdir aaa
```

Back in terminal A:
```
$ ls
ls: reading directory '.': No such file or directory
thread 'main' panicked at 'Unable to identify current directory: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }', src/context.rs:69:51
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace
```

Note that  I need to actually run something (`ls` or `cd` for instance) for the crash to actually happen. 

> This happens to me every time Starship is upgraded by `homebrew` - I have to close all my local terminals and reopen.

I've installed it for the first time today. This is in Archlinux, using the 'community/starship-0.51.0-2' package.

@rmsc Your issue should be fixed by #2520, which isn't in any release yet.

@teancom I think your issue is a different one (#910). There is [a workaround](https://github.com/starship/starship/issues/910#issuecomment-646364785) for it.
